texts.orig: I've started a  series of posts on options trading  and if you haven't read yesterdays post,  Options trading introduction , you should start there first.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Recap: Buying calls and puts
texts.text: Recap: Buying calls and puts

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Buying calls is a great way to capture gains from a stock that is trending upwards an buying puts provides an insurance policy in case your stock drops.
texts.text: Buying calls is a great way to capture gains from a stock that is trending upwards an buying puts provides an insurance policy in case your stock drops.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can make money in multiple ways:
texts.text: You can make money in multiple ways:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Exercising a call option to buy stock at a reduced price (without owning the
texts.text: Exercising a call option to buy stock at a reduced price (without owning the

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Exercising a put option to sell your stock at a higher price (and reduce
texts.text: Exercising a put option to sell your stock at a higher price (and reduce

texts.orig: The stock moves towards (and hopefully, past) your strike price and you can

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: But there's an entirely other world out there and it involves  selling options .
texts.text: But there's an entirely other world out there and it involves  selling options .

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Rights versus Obligations
texts.text: Rights versus Obligations

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: So far, we've only talked about rights. When you buy an options contract, you have the right to do nothing, exercise the option, or sell it away to someone else.
texts.text: So far, we've only talked about rights. When you buy an options contract, you have the right to do nothing, exercise the option, or sell it away to someone else.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Selling options means you  must fulfill an obligation.  We aren't talking about selling an option you purchased -- that's simply called  selling to close . What we're talking about here is a different concept:  selling to open . This is sometimes called  writing a put  or  writing a call .
texts.text: Selling options means you  must fulfill an obligation.  We aren't talking about selling an option you purchased -- that's simply called  selling to close . What we're talking about here is a different concept:  selling to open . This is sometimes called  writing a put  or  writing a call .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When you sell a contract, you are paid a sum of money called a  premium . The buyer is the one paying the premium to you. Let's dig into what's happening here:
texts.text: When you sell a contract, you are paid a sum of money called a  premium . The buyer is the one paying the premium to you. Let's dig into what's happening here:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You are going out into the market and saying "I'd like to get $200 to sell
texts.text: You are going out into the market and saying "I'd like to get $200 to sell

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: A buyer can choose to take you up on your offer, give you $200, and the
texts.text: A buyer can choose to take you up on your offer, give you $200, and the

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='The contract is written in stone until the expiration date'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='The contract is written in stone until the expiration date'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It's key to remember here that there are only two ways out of an options contract that you sell:
texts.text: It's key to remember here that there are only two ways out of an options contract that you sell:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You buy it back (hopefully at a profit). This is called
texts.text: You buy it back (hopefully at a profit). This is called

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The option expires.
texts.text: The option expires.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are three warnings we must cover before we go any further:
texts.text: There are three warnings we must cover before we go any further:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 💣  Never sell an options contract that you do not intend to fulfill.  Sure, it may sound amazing to receive $4,000 in an instant to sell an option, but eventually that option expires and that can sometimes be a disaster.
texts.text: 💣  Never sell an options contract that you do not intend to fulfill.  Sure, it may sound amazing to receive $4,000 in an instant to sell an option, but eventually that option expires and that can sometimes be a disaster.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 💣  Never assume that you will be able to buy to close your sold contract before expiration.  The market does weird things and you may be stuck with holding your option through expiration or taking a loss before expiration.
texts.text: 💣  Never assume that you will be able to buy to close your sold contract before expiration.  The market does weird things and you may be stuck with holding your option through expiration or taking a loss before expiration.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 💣  Never sell options contracts if you don't have stock or cash to cover them.  Getting stuck in a margin call (or worse) with your broker is not a good place to be.
texts.text: 💣  Never sell options contracts if you don't have stock or cash to cover them.  Getting stuck in a margin call (or worse) with your broker is not a good place to be.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: With that said, about 95% of my current trades involve selling options. More on that later.
texts.text: With that said, about 95% of my current trades involve selling options. More on that later.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Selling puts
texts.text: Selling puts

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We should talk about selling puts first because that concept is a little easier. When you sell a put, you specify a few things:
texts.text: We should talk about selling puts first because that concept is a little easier. When you sell a put, you specify a few things:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Underlying stock ticket (such as AMD, WMT, or TM)
texts.text: Underlying stock ticket (such as AMD, WMT, or TM)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Expiration date
texts.text: Expiration date

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: How much premium you want (this is the
texts.text: How much premium you want (this is the

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The strike price
texts.text: The strike price

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Selling puts can make money in a few different ways. The stock can go up, go sideways (where it hovers around a certain price), or go down a little.
texts.text: Selling puts can make money in a few different ways. The stock can go up, go sideways (where it hovers around a certain price), or go down a little.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's go through an example. You think AMD is likely going to keep its same price or go up over the next few weeks. If AMD is trading at $100 now, you decide to sell a put for $90 and collect $200 in premium.
texts.text: Let's go through an example. You think AMD is likely going to keep its same price or go up over the next few weeks. If AMD is trading at $100 now, you decide to sell a put for $90 and collect $200 in premium.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 🛑  Before entering this trade, ensure you have  at least  $9,000 of cash in your account.  100 shares of AMD could potentially cost you $9,000 if you are assigned -- more on that below.
texts.text: 🛑  Before entering this trade, ensure you have  at least  $9,000 of cash in your account.  100 shares of AMD could potentially cost you $9,000 if you are assigned -- more on that below.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now what?
texts.text: Now what?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AMD skyrockets up to $125
texts.text: AMD skyrockets up to $125

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your put loses value rapidly and you can buy it back for only $25 after a
texts.text: Your put loses value rapidly and you can buy it back for only $25 after a

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You can let your put expire and keep the $200 premium. (Risky!)
texts.text: You can let your put expire and keep the $200 premium. (Risky!)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AMD gets stuck at $100
texts.text: AMD gets stuck at $100

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Over time, your put loses value and you can buy it back at a
texts.text: Over time, your put loses value and you can buy it back at a

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You can let your put expire and keep the $200 premium. (Risky!)
texts.text: You can let your put expire and keep the $200 premium. (Risky!)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AMD falls to $85
texts.text: AMD falls to $85

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You're now in the money and that's not great for a sold option.
texts.text: You're now in the money and that's not great for a sold option.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The buyer will likely exercise the option they bought from you and you
texts.text: The buyer will likely exercise the option they bought from you and you

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Assignment on puts
texts.text: Assignment on puts

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Some traders hear about  assignment  and they run off to hide. Assignment means that the buyer of your contract wants to use their right to exercise.
texts.text: Some traders hear about  assignment  and they run off to hide. Assignment means that the buyer of your contract wants to use their right to exercise.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's go back to the very last example above where we sold a put for $90 and AMD fell to $85. This situation feels scary until you break it down:
texts.text: Let's go back to the very last example above where we sold a put for $90 and AMD fell to $85. This situation feels scary until you break it down:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You keep your $200 no matter what. You sold the contract and that's yours.
texts.text: You keep your $200 no matter what. You sold the contract and that's yours.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You must buy 100 shares of AMD at $90 each.
texts.text: You must buy 100 shares of AMD at $90 each.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: But wait, you have to buy AMD at $90 even though AMD fell to $85! That's your obligation for selling the contract. That means you will lose $500 on the stock purchase. (You bought $8,500 of AMD stock but had to pay $9,000 for it.)
texts.text: But wait, you have to buy AMD at $90 even though AMD fell to $85! That's your obligation for selling the contract. That means you will lose $500 on the stock purchase. (You bought $8,500 of AMD stock but had to pay $9,000 for it.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: All together, you lost $300. You paid $500 extra for the AMD shares but you kept your $200 premium for selling the contract. But, now you have 100 AMD shares worth $8,500 in your account!
texts.text: All together, you lost $300. You paid $500 extra for the AMD shares but you kept your $200 premium for selling the contract. But, now you have 100 AMD shares worth $8,500 in your account!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: What do you do with those?
texts.text: What do you do with those?

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Selling calls
texts.text: Selling calls

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now you have 100 shares of AMD in your account worth $8,500 and you're still down $300. It's time to talk about selling calls. Selling calls and puts involve the same concepts of specifying a strike price, how much premium you want, and an expiration date.
texts.text: Now you have 100 shares of AMD in your account worth $8,500 and you're still down $300. It's time to talk about selling calls. Selling calls and puts involve the same concepts of specifying a strike price, how much premium you want, and an expiration date.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You take a look at the options chain and you see that you can sell an AMD call for the $90 strike price for $250 and it expires in a few weeks. This is called a  covered call  since you own 100 shares as collateral for the contract.
texts.text: You take a look at the options chain and you see that you can sell an AMD call for the $90 strike price for $250 and it expires in a few weeks. This is called a  covered call  since you own 100 shares as collateral for the contract.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You sell the call and now there are some potential outcomes:
texts.text: You sell the call and now there are some potential outcomes:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AMD falls to $80
texts.text: AMD falls to $80

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your call loses value rapidly and you can buy it back for a tiny amount.
texts.text: Your call loses value rapidly and you can buy it back for a tiny amount.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Go back and sell another call, collect more premium, and increase your
texts.text: Go back and sell another call, collect more premium, and increase your

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Allow the call to expire worthless and keep your full $250 premium. (Risky!)
texts.text: Allow the call to expire worthless and keep your full $250 premium. (Risky!)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AMD gets stuck at $85
texts.text: AMD gets stuck at $85

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your call gradually loses value and you can buy it back for a tiny amount.
texts.text: Your call gradually loses value and you can buy it back for a tiny amount.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Go back and sell another call, collect more premium, and increase your
texts.text: Go back and sell another call, collect more premium, and increase your

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AMD climbs to $95
texts.text: AMD climbs to $95

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You're now in the money here.
texts.text: You're now in the money here.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: When the option expires, the buyer of your contract will likely want to
texts.text: When the option expires, the buyer of your contract will likely want to

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your shares are gone. (But keep reading.)
texts.text: Your shares are gone. (But keep reading.)

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Assignment on calls
texts.text: Assignment on calls

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Getting assigned on puts means you have to buy the stock at your stike price. Getting assigned on calls is a little different. You  sell  your stock at the strike price to the person who bought your call option contract.
texts.text: Getting assigned on puts means you have to buy the stock at your stike price. Getting assigned on calls is a little different. You  sell  your stock at the strike price to the person who bought your call option contract.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's go back to the previous example where you sold a $90 call option for $250 and AMD went to $95 per share:
texts.text: Let's go back to the previous example where you sold a $90 call option for $250 and AMD went to $95 per share:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You keep your $250 premium since you sold the contract.
texts.text: You keep your $250 premium since you sold the contract.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You sell your 100 AMD shares at $90 each (your strike price) even though AMD
texts.text: You sell your 100 AMD shares at $90 each (your strike price) even though AMD

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Technically, you lost out on $500 of profit that you could have received if you had not sold the call. However, you keep the $250 of premium and you can begin selling puts again.
texts.text: Technically, you lost out on $500 of profit that you could have received if you had not sold the call. However, you keep the $250 of premium and you can begin selling puts again.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Why not just buy stock and hold it?
texts.text: Why not just buy stock and hold it?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I have accounts where I buy stock and hold it for a long time. However, selling options allows you to collect premium and get profits even in a market that isn't moving much.
texts.text: I have accounts where I buy stock and hold it for a long time. However, selling options allows you to collect premium and get profits even in a market that isn't moving much.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If a stock gets stuck in a sideways pattern where it doesn't move much for weeks, buying and holding the stock might give you a very small gain. During that time, you may have been able to get a better return selling options on that stock and collecting the premium.
texts.text: If a stock gets stuck in a sideways pattern where it doesn't move much for weeks, buying and holding the stock might give you a very small gain. During that time, you may have been able to get a better return selling options on that stock and collecting the premium.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: What's the worst that can happen?
texts.text: What's the worst that can happen?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It's always important to know what your max loss is for any trade. Losses begin when the stock price breaches your breakeven price:
texts.text: It's always important to know what your max loss is for any trade. Losses begin when the stock price breaches your breakeven price:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Put breakeven = strike price - premium received
texts.text: Put breakeven = strike price - premium received

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Call breakeven = strike price + premium received
texts.text: Call breakeven = strike price + premium received

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you sell a $90 put for $200 and the stock falls to $89, you are still up $100. If you sell a $90 call for $200 and the stock goes up to $91.50, you are still up $50.
texts.text: If you sell a $90 put for $200 and the stock falls to $89, you are still up $100. If you sell a $90 call for $200 and the stock goes up to $91.50, you are still up $50.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, if you are selling puts or calls, there is a chance that the stock could completely crater and go to zero. The chances of that happening to a well-known company that has been on the market for years is  very low , but it's important to know max loss.
texts.text: However, if you are selling puts or calls, there is a chance that the stock could completely crater and go to zero. The chances of that happening to a well-known company that has been on the market for years is  very low , but it's important to know max loss.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's say you sold a put on company XYZ at the $100 strike and received $500 in premium. The stock somehow falls to $1 per share. Your max loss here is
texts.text: Let's say you sold a put on company XYZ at the $100 strike and received $500 in premium. The stock somehow falls to $1 per share. Your max loss here is

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . The buyer of your options contract will  surely  want to exercise so they can sell their XYZ stock at $100 instead of $1.
texts.text: . The buyer of your options contract will  surely  want to exercise so they can sell their XYZ stock at $100 instead of $1.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: On the call side, let's say you sold a $110 call on XYZ for $500 and the stock fell to $1. The 100 shares of XYZ you own would now be worth $1 per share, but you do keep your $500 premium. If you had owned the shares without selling that call at that time, you would have suffered the same fate (without getting $500 in premium).
texts.text: On the call side, let's say you sold a $110 call on XYZ for $500 and the stock fell to $1. The 100 shares of XYZ you own would now be worth $1 per share, but you do keep your $500 premium. If you had owned the shares without selling that call at that time, you would have suffered the same fate (without getting $500 in premium).

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: The Wheel
texts.text: The Wheel

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The strategy shown here is called the wheel strategy. It involves these steps:
texts.text: The strategy shown here is called the wheel strategy. It involves these steps:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Sell puts and collect premium
texts.text: Sell puts and collect premium

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: If unassigned, go back to step 1
texts.text: If unassigned, go back to step 1

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: If assigned, sell calls and collect premium
texts.text: If assigned, sell calls and collect premium

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: If unassigned, go back to step 3
texts.text: If unassigned, go back to step 3

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: If assigned, go back to step 1
texts.text: If assigned, go back to step 1

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This strategy will be covered in the next post!
texts.text: This strategy will be covered in the next post!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Disclaimer: Keep in mind that I am not an investment professional and you should make your own decisions around stock research and trades. Investing comes with plenty of risk and I'm the last person who should be giving anyone investment advice.  😜
texts.text: Disclaimer: Keep in mind that I am not an investment professional and you should make your own decisions around stock research and trades. Investing comes with plenty of risk and I'm the last person who should be giving anyone investment advice.  😜
